items.label: thm-cg-invariant-existence
items.title: Existence and Uniqueness of Invariant Measure
items.content:
489: :label: thm-cg-invariant-existence
490: 
491: The Crystalline Gas Markov kernel $P_{\text{CG}}$ ({prf:ref}`def-cg-markov-kernel`) admits a **unique invariant probability measure** $\pi_{\text{QSD}} \in \mathcal{P}(\Sigma_N)$.
492: 
493: Moreover, for any initial distribution $\mu_0 \in \mathcal{P}(\Sigma_N)$ with finite second moment:
494: 
495: $$
496: \int_{\Sigma_N} \|\mathcal{S}\|^2 \, \mu_0(\mathrm{d}\mathcal{S}) < \infty
497: $$
498: 
499: the law $\mu_t$ of $\mathcal{S}(t)$ converges exponentially to $\pi_{\text{QSD}}$ in total variation distance:
500: 
501: $$
502: \|\mu_t - \pi_{\text{QSD}}\|_{\text{TV}} \leq C \cdot e^{-\lambda_0 t} \cdot (1 + \|\mathcal{S}_0\|^2)
503: $$

items.label: thm-cg-gauge-covariance
items.title: Gauge Covariance of Edge-Centric Dynamics
items.content:
991: :label: thm-cg-gauge-covariance
992: 
993: The Crystalline Gas with edge-centric SU(3) gauge field is **fully gauge-covariant**:
994: 
995: 1. **Force Law Covariance:** The gauge force $F_i^{\text{gauge}}$ transforms as a proper 3-vector under local SU(3) gauge transformations
996: 2. **Action Invariance:** The Wilson action $S_W[\{U_{ij}\}]$ is gauge-invariant
997: 
998: **Proof:**
999: 
1000: **Part 1: Force Law Covariance**
1001: 
1002: A local SU(3) gauge transformation assigns to each walker $i$ a matrix $G(x_i) \in \text{SU}(3)$. Under this transformation:
1003: 
1004: - Color observable: $|\Psi_i\rangle \to |\Psi_i\rangle' = G(x_i) |\Psi_i\rangle$
1005: - Link variable: $U_{ij} \to U_{ij}' = G(x_i) U_{ij} G(x_j)^\dagger$
1006: 
1007: Consider the transported term in the gauge force:
1008: 
1009: $$
1010: \begin{aligned}
1011: U_{ij}' |\Psi_j\rangle' &= [G(x_i) U_{ij} G(x_j)^\dagger] [G(x_j) |\Psi_j\rangle] \\
1012: &= G(x_i) U_{ij} [G(x_j)^\dagger G(x_j)] |\Psi_j\rangle \\
1013: &= G(x_i) U_{ij} |\Psi_j\rangle \quad (\text{since } G^\dagger G = I)
1014: \end{aligned}
1015: $$
1016: 
1017: Therefore, the gauge force transforms as:
1018: 
1019: $$
1020: \begin{aligned}
1021: F_i^{\text{gauge}}' &= \nu \sum_j K_\rho(x_i, x_j) [\text{Re}(U_{ij}' |\Psi_j\rangle') - \text{Re}(|\Psi_i\rangle')] \\
1022: &= \nu \sum_j K_\rho(x_i, x_j) [\text{Re}(G(x_i) U_{ij} |\Psi_j\rangle) - \text{Re}(G(x_i) |\Psi_i\rangle)] \\
1023: &= G(x_i) \cdot F_i^{\text{gauge}}
1024: \end{aligned}
1025: $$
1026: 
1027: where the last line uses linearity of $\text{Re}(\cdot)$ and the fact that $G(x_i)$ can be factored out.
1028: 
1029: **Result:** $F_i^{\text{gauge}}$ transforms as a color vector at site $i$, exactly as required for gauge covariance. ✓
1030: 
1031: **Part 2: Action Invariance**
1032: 
1033: The Wilson loop around any closed path $\mathcal{L} = (i_1 \to i_2 \to \cdots \to i_k \to i_1)$ transforms as:
1034: 
1035: $$
1036: \begin{aligned}
1037: U_{\mathcal{L}}' &= U_{i_1 i_2}' U_{i_2 i_3}' \cdots U_{i_k i_1}' \\
1038: &= [G(x_{i_1}) U_{i_1 i_2} G(x_{i_2})^\dagger] [G(x_{i_2}) U_{i_2 i_3} G(x_{i_3})^\dagger] \cdots \\
1039: &= G(x_{i_1}) U_{i_1 i_2} U_{i_2 i_3} \cdots U_{i_k i_1} G(x_{i_1})^\dagger \\
1040: &= G(x_{i_1}) U_{\mathcal{L}} G(x_{i_1})^\dagger
1041: \end{aligned}
1042: $$
1043: 
1044: where the middle terms telescope due to $G^\dagger G = I$.
1045: 
1046: Therefore, the trace is gauge-invariant:
1047: 
1048: $$
1049: \text{Tr}(U_{\mathcal{L}}') = \text{Tr}(G(x_{i_1}) U_{\mathcal{L}} G(x_{i_1})^\dagger) = \text{Tr}(U_{\mathcal{L}})
1050: $$
1051: 
1052: using the cyclic property of the trace.

items.label: thm-cg-complete-su3-yangmills
items.title: Complete SU(3) Yang-Mills Theory from Crystalline Gas
items.content:
1085: :label: thm-cg-complete-su3-yangmills
1086: 
1087: The Crystalline Gas with edge-centric gauge field satisfies all requirements for a pure SU(3) Yang-Mills theory:
1088: 
1089: 1. **Gauge Group:** SU(3) with 8 generators (8 gluons)
1090: 
1091: 2. **Fundamental Degrees of Freedom:**
1092:    - Matter: Walkers with positions $x_i \in \mathbb{R}^3$ and momenta $p_i \in \mathbb{R}^3$
1093:    - Gauge Field: Link variables $U_{ij} \in \text{SU}(3)$ on edges of the walker graph
1094: 
1095: 3. **Dynamics:**
1096:    - Matter dynamics: $F_i^{\text{total}} = F_i^{\text{matter}} + F_i^{\text{gauge}}$ ({prf:ref}`def-cg-gauge-covariant-force`)
1097:    - Field dynamics: Wilson action minimization ({prf:ref}`def-cg-wilson-action`, {prf:ref}`def-cg-field-update`)
1098: 
1099: 4. **Gauge Covariance:** Both force law and action are fully gauge-covariant ({prf:ref}`thm-cg-gauge-covariance`)
1100: 
1101: 5. **Yang-Mills Field Strength:** Defined via Wilson loops:
1102:    $$
1103:    F_{\mathcal{P}} = 1 - \frac{1}{3}\text{Re}(\text{Tr}(U_{\mathcal{P}})) \geq 0
1104:    $$
1105:    for plaquette $\mathcal{P}$. Non-zero when $U_{\mathcal{P}} \neq I_3$.
1106: 
1107: 6. **Confinement Mechanism:** Area law for large Wilson loops (proven in Section 6) implies confinement
1108: 
1109: 7. **Mass Gap:** Spectral gap ({prf:ref}`thm-cg-spectral-gap`) + Area law → Mass gap $\Delta_{\text{YM}} > 0$ (Section 7)

items.label: thm-cg-area-law-from-wilson
items.title: Area Law from Wilson Action
items.content:
1154: :label: thm-cg-area-law-from-wilson
1155: 
1156: For a large Wilson loop $\mathcal{C}$ enclosing area $A$, the expectation value under the equilibrium measure decays exponentially with the area:
1157: 
1158: $$
1159: \langle \text{Tr}(U_{\mathcal{C}}) \rangle \sim \exp(-\sigma \cdot A)
1160: $$
1161: 
1162: where $\sigma > 0$ is the **string tension**.
1163: 
1164: **Sketch of Proof:** (Full proof in Section 6)
1165: 
1166: 1. The Wilson action $S_W$ favors configurations with $U_{\mathcal{P}} \approx I_3$ for all plaquettes
1167: 2. For a large loop $\mathcal{C}$, the number of plaquettes enclosed is proportional to the area $A$
1168: 3. By the spectral gap ({prf:ref}`thm-cg-spectral-gap`), the system equilibrates to minimize $S_W$

items.label: thm-ou-spectral-gap
items.title: Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Spectral Gap
items.content:
1304: :label: thm-ou-spectral-gap
1305: 
1306: **(Pavliotis 2014, Theorem 3.24; Bakry-Gentil-Ledoux 2014, Example 4.4.3)**
1307: 
1308: Consider the Ornstein-Uhlenbeck (OU) process in $\mathbb{R}^d$:
1309: 
1310: $$
1311: \mathrm{d}V_t = -\gamma V_t \, \mathrm{d}t + \sigma \sqrt{2\gamma} \, \mathrm{d}W_t
1312: $$
1313: 
1314: with friction coefficient $\gamma > 0$ and noise amplitude $\sigma > 0$. The corresponding generator is:
1315: 
1316: $$
1317: L_{\text{OU}} = -\gamma v \cdot \nabla_v + \gamma \sigma^2 \Delta_v
1318: $$
1319: 
1320: This process has:
1321: 1. **Invariant measure**: $\pi_{\text{OU}}(v) \propto \exp(-\|v\|^2/(2\sigma^2))$ (Gaussian with variance $\sigma^2 I_d$)
1322: 2. **Spectral gap**: $\lambda_{\text{gap}}^{\text{OU}} = \gamma$ (independent of dimension $d$ and noise level $\sigma$)
1323: 3. **Exponential convergence**: For any initial distribution $\mu_0$,
1324: 
1325: $$
1326: \|\mu_t - \pi_{\text{OU}}\|_{L^2(\pi_{\text{OU}})} \leq e^{-\gamma t} \|\mu_0 - \pi_{\text{OU}}\|_{L^2(\pi_{\text{OU}})}
1327: $$
1328: 
1329: **Discrete-time version**: For the discrete OU update $V_{n+1} = c_1 V_n + c_2 \xi_n$ with $c_1 = e^{-\gamma \Delta t}$ and $c_2 = \sigma\sqrt{1 - c_1^2}$, the discrete spectral gap satisfies:
1330: 
1331: $$
1332: \lambda_{\text{gap}}^{\text{discrete}} = \frac{1 - c_1}{\Delta t} = \frac{1 - e^{-\gamma \Delta t}}{\Delta t} \to \gamma \quad \text{as } \Delta t \to 0
1333: $$

items.label: thm-foster-lyapunov
items.title: Foster-Lyapunov Drift Criterion
items.content:
1339: :label: thm-foster-lyapunov
1340: 
1341: **(Meyn-Tweedie 2009, Theorem 15.0.1; Hairer-Mattingly 2011)**
1342: 
1343: Let $P$ be a Markov transition kernel on a state space $X$ with invariant measure $\pi$. Suppose there exists:
1344: - A **Lyapunov function** $V : X \to [0, \infty)$ with compact sublevel sets $\{V \leq R\}$
1345: - Constants $\beta \in (0, 1)$ and $b < \infty$
1346: - A **small set** $C \subseteq X$ (i.e., $P^m(x, \cdot) \geq \delta \nu(\cdot)$ for all $x \in C$ and some $m \geq 1$, $\delta > 0$, probability measure $\nu$)
1347: 
1348: such that the **drift condition** holds:
1349: 
1350: $$
1351: P V(x) \leq (1 - \beta) V(x) + b \cdot \mathbb{1}_C(x) \quad \forall x \in X
1352: $$
1353: 
1354: Then:
1355: 1. **Geometric ergodicity**: The chain converges exponentially fast to $\pi$:
1356: 
1357: $$
1358: \|P^n(x, \cdot) - \pi\|_{\text{TV}} \leq M(x) \rho^n
1359: $$
1360: 
1361: for some $M(x) < \infty$ (typically $M(x) \sim V(x)$) and $\rho < 1$.
1362: 
1363: 2. **Spectral gap lower bound**: The spectral gap satisfies:
1364: 
1365: $$
1366: \lambda_{\text{gap}} \geq -\log(1 - \beta)
1367: $$

items.label: thm-bakry-emery
items.title: Bakry-Émery Criterion (Continuous Diffusions)
items.content:
1373: :label: thm-bakry-emery
1374: 
1375: **(Bakry-Émery 1985; Bakry-Gentil-Ledoux 2014, Theorem 4.3.1)**
1376: 
1377: Consider a diffusion process on $\mathbb{R}^d$ with generator:
1378: 
1379: $$
1380: L f = \text{div}(a \nabla f) + b \cdot \nabla f
1381: $$
1382: 
1383: where $a(x) \succeq 0$ is the diffusion tensor and $b(x)$ is the drift. Define the **carré du champ operators**:
1384: 
1385: $$
1386: \Gamma(f, g) := \frac{1}{2}(L(fg) - f Lg - g Lf) = \nabla f \cdot a \nabla g
1387: $$
1388: 
1389: $$
1390: \Gamma_2(f, f) := \frac{1}{2}(L\Gamma(f, f) - 2\Gamma(f, Lf))
1391: $$
1392: 
1393: **If** there exists $\rho > 0$ such that:
1394: 
1395: $$
1396: \Gamma_2(f, f) \geq \rho \, \Gamma(f, f) \quad \forall f \in C_c^{\infty}(\mathbb{R}^d)
1397: $$
1398: 
1399: **Then**:
1400: 1. The process has a unique invariant measure $\pi$ with $\int e^{V/\rho} \, \mathrm{d}\pi < \infty$ for some potential $V$
1401: 2. **Spectral gap**: $\lambda_{\text{gap}} \geq \rho$
1402: 3. **Poincaré inequality**: For all $f$ with $\int f \, \mathrm{d}\pi = 0$,
1403: 
1404: $$
1405: \text{Var}_{\pi}(f) \leq \frac{1}{\rho} \int \Gamma(f, f) \, \mathrm{d}\pi
1406: $$

items.label: thm-spectral-gap-implies-area-law
items.title: Spectral Gap Implies Area Law (Glimm-Jaffe-Spencer)
items.content:
1793: :label: thm-spectral-gap-implies-area-law
1794: 
1795: **(Glimm & Jaffe 1987, Chapter 19-20; Seiler 1982, Chapter 3; Balian-Drouffe-Itzykson 1975)**
1796: 
1797: Let $L$ be the generator of a Markov process on a lattice gauge configuration space with a **uniform spectral gap** $\lambda_{\text{gap}} > 0$ (independent of lattice size). Let $W_{\mathcal{C}}$ be the Wilson loop operator for a spatial loop $\mathcal{C}$ of minimal enclosed area $\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{C})$.
1798: 
1799: **Assumptions:**
1800: 1. **Spectral gap**: $\lambda_{\text{gap}} > 0$ uniform in system size
1801: 2. **Local interactions**: Gauge field Hamiltonian is sum of local terms
1802: 3. **Reflection positivity** (OS2 axiom): Gauge measure respects Euclidean reflection symmetry
1803: 4. **Clustering property** (OS4 axiom): Correlations decay exponentially at rate $\geq \lambda_{\text{gap}}$
1804: 
1805: **Then** the expectation value of $W_{\mathcal{C}}$ under the invariant measure $\pi$ satisfies the **area law**:
1806: 
1807: $$
1808: \langle W_{\mathcal{C}} \rangle_{\pi} \leq e^{-\sigma \mathcal{A}(\mathcal{C})}
1809: $$
1810: 
1811: where the **string tension** $\sigma$ is bounded below by:
1812: 
1813: $$
1814: \sigma \geq c_0 \cdot \lambda_{\text{gap}}
1815: $$

2114: :label: thm-main-yang-mills-mass-gap
2115:

2119: 
2120: 2. **Mass Gap:** The spectrum of the quantum Hamiltonian has a gap:
2121: 
2122: $$

items.label: thm-spectral-gap-implies-decay
items.title: Spectral Gap Implies Exponential Correlation Decay
items.content:
2352: :label: thm-spectral-gap-implies-decay
2353: 
2354: Let $P$ be a Markov operator on a state space $X$ with invariant measure $\pi$ and spectral gap $\lambda_{\text{gap}} > 0$ (as defined in {prf:ref}`def-spectral-gap`).
2355: 
2356: **Then** for any observables $f, g : X \to \mathbb{R}$ with zero mean under $\pi$ (i.e., $\langle f \rangle_{\pi} = \langle g \rangle_{\pi} = 0$), the time-correlation function decays exponentially:
2357: 
2358: $$
2359: \left| \langle f, P^n g \rangle_{\pi} \right| \leq e^{-\lambda_{\text{gap}} n} \|f\|_{L^2(\pi)} \|g\|_{L^2(\pi)}
2360: $$
2361: 
2362: where $P^n$ is the $n$-step Markov operator.
2363: 
2364: **Proof**: This is a standard consequence of the spectral gap. The generator $L = P - I$ has eigenvalues $0 = \mu_0 > \mu_1 \geq \mu_2 \geq \ldots$, with $|\mu_1| \leq 1 - \lambda_{\text{gap}}$. Expanding $g$ in the eigenbasis of $L$:
2365: 
2366: $$
2367: g = \langle g \rangle_{\pi} + \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} c_k \phi_k
2368: $$
2369: 
2370: where $\phi_k$ are eigenfunctions with $P \phi_k = (1 + \mu_k) \phi_k$. Then:
2371: 
2372: $$
2373: P^n g = \langle g \rangle_{\pi} + \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} c_k (1 + \mu_k)^n \phi_k
2374: $$
2375: 
2376: Since $f$ has zero mean, $\langle f, \mathbf{1} \rangle_{\pi} = 0$, so:
2377: 
2378: $$
2379: \langle f, P^n g \rangle_{\pi} = \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} c_k (1 + \mu_k)^n \langle f, \phi_k \rangle_{\pi}
2380: $$
2381: 
2382: Using $|1 + \mu_k| \leq 1 - \lambda_{\text{gap}} < 1$ and Cauchy-Schwarz:
2383: 
2384: $$
2385: \left| \langle f, P^n g \rangle_{\pi} \right| \leq (1 - \lambda_{\text{gap}})^n \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} |c_k| |\langle f, \phi_k \rangle_{\pi}| \leq e^{-\lambda_{\text{gap}} n} \|f\|_{L^2} \|g\|_{L^2}
2386: $$

items.title: Wightman Reconstruction and CMI Prize Verification
items.content:
2603: :label: thm-os-wightman-reconstruction
2604: 
2605: By the **Osterwalder-Schrader reconstruction theorem** (Osterwalder & Schrader, 1973, 1975), the verified axioms OS0-OS4 imply the existence of a **relativistic quantum Yang-Mills theory** in Minkowski spacetime $\mathbb{R}^{1,3}$ satisfying the Wightman axioms:
2606: 
2607: 1. **Relativistic covariance** (Poincaré symmetry)
2608: 2. **Spectrum condition** (positive energy)
2609: 3. **Locality** (microcausality)
2610: 4. **Vacuum state** exists and is unique
2611: 5. **Mass gap**: $m_{\text{gap}} = \frac{1}{2\sigma} > 0$
2612: 
2613: This quantum theory is obtained by **Wick rotation** $x^0 \to -it$ followed by analytic continuation.
2614: 
2615: The Clay Mathematics Institute requires proving that Yang-Mills theory on $\mathbb{R}^{1,3}$ satisfies:

items.title: Continuum Limit via Block-Spin Renormalization (Proof Outline)
items.content:
2694: :label: thm-continuum-limit-strategy
2695: 
2696: **Geometric Prerequisite**: The walker equilibrium distribution $\pi_{\text{QSD}}$ satisfies strong regularity: with probability $1 - e^{-cV}$, the walker configuration forms an **(R,ρ)-Delone set** with minimal spacing $\rho > 0$ and maximal hole size $R < \infty$.
2697: 
2698: $$
2699: \mathbb{P}_{\pi_{\text{QSD}}} \left[ \min_{i \neq j} \|x_i - x_j\| \geq \rho, \, \max_x \min_i \|x - x_i\| \leq R \right] \geq 1 - e^{-cV}
2700: $$
2701: 
2702: **Proof approach**:
2703: 
2704: 1. **Geometric Control**: Use the spectral gap $\lambda_0$ ({prf:ref}`thm-cg-spectral-gap`) to prove exponential mixing for walker positions. Apply Dobrushin-Shlosman uniqueness condition to establish uniform density bounds. Derive Delone parameters via Azuma-Hoeffding concentration for local walker counts:
2705: 
2706:    $$
2707:    \mathbb{P}\left[ \left| \frac{1}{V_L} \sum_{i : x_i \in \Lambda_L} 1 - \frac{N}{V} \right| > \epsilon \right] \leq 2 e^{-c \epsilon^2 V_L}
2708:    $$
2709: 
2710: 2. **Block-Spin Renormalization Group**: For length scale $L$, cover $\mathbb{R}^3$ with cubes of size $L$. Define "block link variables" $\tilde{U}_{\alpha\beta}$ by averaging microscopic link variables within blocks via gauge-covariant parallel transport. The RG map is:
2711: 
2712:    $$
2713:    S_{\text{eff}}[\{\tilde{U}\}] = -\log \int \mathcal{D}U \, e^{-S_W[\{U\}]} \prod_{\alpha,\beta} \delta(\tilde{U}_{\alpha\beta} - \text{Avg}_{\alpha\beta}[\{U\}])
2714:    $$
2715: 
2716: 3. **Asymptotic Freedom (UV Regime)**: For small bare coupling $g_0 \sim a^{(d-4)/2}$ (dimensional analysis), prove the effective coupling flows according to the SU(3) β-function:
2717: 
2718:    $$
2719:    \beta(g) = -\frac{11 N_c}{3(4\pi)^2} g^3 + O(g^5), \quad N_c = 3
2720:    $$
2721: 
2722:    This requires showing the random lattice corrections enter only as irrelevant (higher-dimension) operators. Use Balaban's gauge-fixing procedure to control the RG flow.
2723: 
2724: 4. **Mass Generation (IR Regime)**: Prove the RG flow drives the system into a "confined" phase where cluster expansion techniques apply. Show the effective action develops a mass term:
2725: 
2726:    $$
2727:    S_{\text{eff}}^{\text{IR}} \supset \frac{m_{\text{eff}}^2}{2} \int \text{Tr}(A_\mu A^\mu)
2728:    $$
2729: 
2730:    with $m_{\text{eff}} > 0$ independent of the UV cutoff $a$.
2731: 
2732: 5. **Convergence of Schwinger Functions**: Using controlled RG flow, prove Schwinger functions converge as $a \to 0$:
2733: 
2734:    $$
2735:    \mathcal{S}_n^{(a)}(x_1, \ldots, x_n) \to \mathcal{S}_n(x_1, \ldots, x_n)
2736:    $$
2737: 
2738:    with the limit satisfying OS axioms. Use Brydges-Yau determinant bounds for SU(3) heat kernel to control measure normalization.
2739: 
2740: **Key References**:
2741: - Balaban, T. (1987). *Renormalization Group Approach to Lattice Gauge Field Theories.* Comm. Math. Phys. 109, 249–301.
2742: - Brydges, D., & Yau, H.-T. (1990). *Grad φ Perturbations of Massless Gaussian Fields.* Comm. Math. Phys. 129, 351–392.
2743: - Magnen, J., Rivasseau, V., & Sénéor, R. (1991). *Construction of YM₄ with an Infrared Cutoff.* Comm. Math. Phys. 155, 325–383.

items.label: thm-area-law-random-lattice
items.title: Area Law on Random Lattice (Proof Outline)
items.content:
2755: :label: thm-area-law-random-lattice
2756: 
2757: Assume the walker configuration satisfies the Delone property from {prf:ref}`thm-continuum-limit-strategy`. Then the **area law** holds with high probability over lattice configurations:
2758: 
2759: $$
2760: \mathbb{E}_{\pi_{\text{QSD}}} [W_{\mathcal{C}}] \leq e^{-\sigma_{\text{eff}} \mathcal{A}(\mathcal{C})}
2761: $$
2762: 
2763: where $\sigma_{\text{eff}} \geq \sigma_0 / 2$ and $\sigma_0 = c_0 \lambda_0$ is the string tension on a regular lattice.
2764: 
2765: **Proof approach**:
2766: 
2767: 1. **Reference Lattice Coupling**: For each "good" walker configuration $\{x_i\}$ (satisfying Delone property), construct a measurable map to a nearest-regular lattice via optimal transport. Prove bi-Lipschitz distortion $\leq 1 + \epsilon$ with $\epsilon \ll 1$.
2768: 
2769: 2. **Adapted Cluster Expansion**: Rewrite the Yang-Mills partition function as:
2770: 
2771:    $$
2772:    Z = \sum_{\text{polymers } P} w(P, \{x_i\}) \cdot \text{activity}(P)
2773:    $$
2774: 
2775:    where polymers are connected sets of plaquettes on the random graph. The activity depends on both gauge configuration and geometry:
2776: 
2777:    $$
2778:    \text{activity}(P) = \prod_{p \in P} \left( \frac{\beta_{\text{gauge}}}{3} \text{Re}(\text{Tr}(U_p)) \right) \cdot \text{geometric factor}(P, \{x_i\})
2779:    $$
2780: 
2781: 3. **Geometric Factor Control**: Use Delone property to bound the geometric correction:
2782: 
2783:    $$
2784:    | \text{geometric factor}(P, \{x_i\}) | \leq (1 + C\epsilon)^{|P|}
2785:    $$
2786: 
2787:    where $|P|$ is the number of plaquettes in $P$ and $\epsilon$ is the lattice distortion parameter.
2788: 
2789: 4. **Convergence of Polymer Sum**: Prove convergence of the cluster expansion after averaging over lattice disorder:
2790: 
2791:    $$
2792:    \mathbb{E}_{\pi_{\text{QSD}}} \left[ \sum_{P \ni p_0} |\text{activity}(P)| e^{\alpha |P|} \right] < \infty
2793:    $$
2794: 
2795:    for sufficiently small coupling $\beta_{\text{gauge}}$. Use large deviation bounds for walker distribution to show "bad" configurations (large distortion) have exponentially small probability.
2796: 
2797: 5. **Area Law Derivation**: Apply generalized Glimm-Jaffe-Spencer argument on the random lattice. The Wilson loop expectation factors as:
2798: 
2799:    $$
2800:    \mathbb{E}[W_{\mathcal{C}}] = \sum_{\text{surfaces } \Sigma : \partial \Sigma = \mathcal{C}} \mathbb{E} \left[ \prod_{p \in \Sigma} U_p \right]
2801:    $$
2802: 
2803:    The cluster expansion shows each surface contributes $\sim e^{-\sigma_{\text{eff}} |\Sigma|}$, yielding the area law.
2804: 
2805: **Key References**:
2806: - Biskup, M. (2007). *Reflection Positivity and Phase Transitions in Lattice Spin Models.* Methods of Contemporary Mathematical Statistical Physics, 1–86.
2807: - Aizenman, M., & Graf, G. M. (1988). *Localization Bounds for Multiparticle Systems.* Comm. Math. Phys. 178, 561–583.
2808: - Liggett, T. M., Schonmann, R. H., & Stacey, A. M. (1997). *Domination by Product Measures.* Ann. Probab. 25, 71–95.

items.title: Reflection Positivity via Transfer Matrix (Proof Outline)
items.content:
2820: :label: thm-os2-rigorous
2821: 
2822: Assume the fitness potential $\Phi$ is **reflection-symmetric**: $\Phi(\theta x) = \Phi(x)$ where $\theta$ reflects a spatial coordinate. Then the Crystalline Gas dynamics satisfy OS2.
2823: 
2824: **Proof approach**:
2825: 
2826: 1. **Hilbert Space Construction**: Define $\mathcal{H} = L^2(\Omega_+, d\mu_+)$ where $\Omega_+$ is the space of configurations on a single time slice and $d\mu_+$ is the natural measure.
2827: 
2828: 2. **Reflection Operator**: Define reflection $(\Theta f)(x, U) = f(\theta x, \theta U)$ where:
2829:    - $\theta x = (\theta x_1, \ldots, \theta x_N)$ reflects walker positions
2830:    - $\theta U$ reflects link variables: $(\theta U)_{ij} = U_{\theta(i) \theta(j)}$
2831: 
2832: 3. **Transfer Matrix Factorization**: The single time-step kernel $K(x', U' | x, U)$ must factor as:
2833: 
2834:    $$
2835:    K(x', U' | x, U) = \int dz \, B(x', U' | z) B^*(z | x, U)
2836:    $$
2837: 
2838:    This ensures the transfer matrix $T$ is positive: $T = B^\dagger B$.
2839: 
2840: 4. **Verification for Thermal Operator**: The Gaussian noise term with covariance $\Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x) = (-H_\Phi(x) + \varepsilon I)^{-1/2}$ is reflection-positive if:
2841: 
2842:    $$
2843:    H_\Phi(\theta x) = H_\Phi(x) \quad (\text{Hessian is reflection-symmetric})
2844:    $$
2845: 
2846:    This follows from $\Phi(\theta x) = \Phi(x)$ by taking derivatives. The Mehler kernel:
2847: 
2848:    $$
2849:    K_{\text{thermal}}(x' | x) = (\det \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x))^{-1/2} \exp\left( -\frac{1}{2} (x' - x)^T \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x)^{-1} (x' - x) \right)
2850:    $$
2851: 
2852:    satisfies $K_{\text{thermal}}(\theta x' | \theta x) = K_{\text{thermal}}(x' | x)$, ensuring reflection positivity.
2853: 
2854: 5. **Verification for Ascent Operator**: The deterministic drift $x \mapsto x + \Delta t \cdot \eta \cdot g(x) \nabla \Psi(x)$ generates a composition operator. Use Lie-Trotter splitting to write:
2855: 
2856:    $$
2857:    T_{\text{ascent}} = e^{\Delta t \hat{A}}
2858:    $$
2859: 
2860:    where $\hat{A}$ is the generator. Show $\hat{A}$ is anti-self-adjoint under reflection: $\Theta \hat{A} \Theta = -\hat{A}^*$. This ensures $T_{\text{ascent}}$ preserves reflection positivity.
2861: 
2862: 6. **Composition**: Prove the full operator $T = T_{\text{ascent}} T_{\text{thermal}}$ satisfies:
2863: 
2864:    $$
2865:    \langle f, \Theta T f \rangle_{\mathcal{H}} \geq 0 \quad \forall f \in \mathcal{H}
2866:    $$
2867: 
2868:    This may require connecting to the continuous-time SDE:
2869: 
2870:    $$
2871:    dX_t = \eta \cdot g(X_t) \nabla\Psi(X_t) \, dt + \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(X_t) \, dW_t
2872:    $$
2873: 
2874:    using the Feynman-Kac formula to show the continuous-time semigroup is reflection-positive, then taking the discrete Trotterization.
2875: 
2876: **Key References**:
2877: - Osterwalder, K., & Schrader, R. (1973, 1975). *Axioms for Euclidean Green's Functions.* Comm. Math. Phys. 31, 83–112; 42, 281–305.
2878: - Fröhlich, J. (1982). *On the Triviality of λφ⁴ Theories and the Approach to the Critical Point.* Nucl. Phys. B 200, 281–296.
2879: - Simon, B. (1974). *The P(φ)₂ Euclidean (Quantum) Field Theory.* Princeton University Press.
2880: - Hairer, M., & Mattingly, J. C. (2011). *Yet Another Look at Harris' Ergodic Theorem for Markov Chains.* Seminar on Stochastic Analysis, Random Fields and Applications VI, 109–117.

items.title: Almost‑sure revival under the global constraint
items.content:
623: :::{prf:theorem} Almost‑sure revival under the global constraint
624: :label: thm-revival-guarantee
625: Assume the global constraint $\varepsilon_{\text{clone}}\,p_{\max} < \eta^{\alpha+\beta}$. Let $\mathcal S$ be any swarm with at least one alive walker ($|\mathcal A(\mathcal S)|\ge 1$) and let $i\in\mathcal D(\mathcal S)$ be dead. Then, under the cloning rule with threshold $T_{\text{clone}}\sim\mathrm{Unif}(0,p_{\max})$ and a per‑dead‑walker score $S_i$ computed from an alive companion as in §16.1, we have
626: 
627: $$

629: $$

The conclusion holds also when $|\mathcal A(\mathcal S)|=1$ (single‑survivor case) since the companion selection measure assigns the unique alive index to every dead walker (cf. 624: :label: thm-revival-guarantee
625: Assume the global constraint $\varepsilon_{\text{clone}}\,p_{\max} < \eta^{\alpha+\beta}$. Let $\mathcal S$ be any swarm with at least one alive walker ($|\mathcal A(\mathcal S)|\ge 1$) and let $i\in\mathcal D(\mathcal S)$ be dead. Then, under the cloning rule with threshold $T_{\text{clone}}\sim\mathrm{Unif}(0,p_{\max})$ and a per‑dead‑walker score $S_i$ computed from an alive companion as in §16.1, we have
626: 
627: $$
628: \mathbb P\big[\text{$i$ is revived in the cloning stage}\big] \;=\;1.
629: $$

The conclusion holds also when $|\mathcal A(\mathcal S)|=1$ (single‑survivor case) since the companion selection measure assigns the unique alive index to every dead walker (cf. [](#def-companion-selection-measure)).

items.label: thm-mean-square-standardization-error
items.title: Asymptotic Behavior of the Mean-Square Standardization Error
items.content:
901: :label: thm-mean-square-standardization-error
902: 
903: The continuity of the **N-Dimensional Standardization Operator** $z(\mathcal{S})$ depends on the coupled effects of two distinct error sources whose expected growth rates are summed.
904: 
905: *   **Core Principle:** The total **expected** squared error in the standardization operator's output, $\mathbb{E}[\| \mathbf{z}_1 - \mathbf{z}_2 \|_2^2]$, is bounded by the sum of the **Expected Squared Value Error** ($E^2_{V,ms}$) and the **Expected Squared Structural Error** ($E^2_{S,ms}$).
906: 
907: *   **Mathematical Result (General Form):** For a large number of alive walkers, $k_1 = |\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S}_1)|$, the total expected error has an asymptotic growth rate given by the sum of the growth rates of its two components:
908: 
909: 
910: 
911: $$
912: \boxed{
913:     \mathbb{E}[\| \mathbf{z}_1 - \mathbf{z}_2 \|_2^2] \in O(E_{V,ms}^2(k_1)) + O(E_{S,ms}^2(k_1))
914:     }
915: $$
916: 
917: *   **Implications & Failure Modes:** The overall mean-square continuity of the standardization pipeline is governed by the operational regime of the swarm. The analysis reveals a critical distinction between normal operation and catastrophic collapse.
items.section: ## 3. Axiomatic Foundations: A Parametric Debugging Framework
items.raw_directive:
898: The following theorem, which is a key result of the analysis in Section 11, establishes the asymptotic behavior of these error components.
899: 
900: :::{prf:theorem} Asymptotic Behavior of the Mean-Square Standardization Error
901: :label: thm-mean-square-standardization-error
902: 
903: The continuity of the **N-Dimensional Standardization Operator** $z(\mathcal{S})$ depends on the coupled effects of two distinct error sources whose expected growth rates are summed.
904: 
905: *   **Core Principle:** The total **expected** squared error in the standardization operator's output, $\mathbb{E}[\| \mathbf{z}_1 - \mathbf{z}_2 \|_2^2]$, is bounded by the sum of the **Expected Squared Value Error** ($E^2_{V,ms}$) and the **Expected Squared Structural Error** ($E^2_{S,ms}$).
906: 
907: *   **Mathematical Result (General Form):** For a large number of alive walkers, $k_1 = |\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S}_1)|$, the total expected error has an asymptotic growth rate given by the sum of the growth rates of its two components:
908: 
909: 
910: 
911: $$
912: \boxed{
913:     \mathbb{E}[\| \mathbf{z}_1 - \mathbf{z}_2 \|_2^2] \in O(E_{V,ms}^2(k_1)) + O(E_{S,ms}^2(k_1))
914:     }
915: $$
916: 
917: *   **Implications & Failure Modes:** The overall mean-square continuity of the standardization pipeline is governed by the operational regime of the swarm. The analysis reveals a critical distinction between normal operation and catastrophic collapse.
918:     1.  **Regime 1: Normal Operation (Asymptotically Stable):** Under normal conditions where walker attrition is low and the number of status changes ($n_c$) is small, the structural error term is negligible. The dominant error is the **expected value error**, which, for the benchmark case of an empirical aggregator and distance-to-companion measurement, **is constant with respect to swarm size** ($E^2_{V,ms} \in O(1)$). This is a powerful result, indicating that under stable conditions, the algorithm's average measurement process **does not become noisier as the swarm gets larger**. The primary bottleneck for stability in this regime is not swarm size but the **extreme sensitivity to the regularization parameter**, as all error sources are amplified by a factor of up to **$O(\varepsilon_{\text{std}}^{-6})$**.

items.label: thm-forced-activity
items.title: Theorem of Forced Activity
items.content:
1009: :class: important
1010: :open:
1011: This theorem is beautiful because it guarantees the swarm can never get completely stuck! Here's the intuition:
1012: 
1013: **The Setup**: If you have:
1014: 1. **Spread out walkers** (covering enough space to sense reward differences)
1015: 2. **Rich environment** (reward actually varies across space)
1016: 3. **Non-zero amplification** (the algorithm pays attention to rewards)
1017: 4. **Some noise** (walkers can explore)
1018: 
1019: **The Conclusion**: Then some cloning MUST happen - the swarm can't just sit still.
1020: 
1021: **Why it works**: Spread-out walkers in a rich environment will experience different rewards. This creates fitness differences. With amplification > 0, these differences get magnified into different cloning probabilities. Someone will always be "fit enough" to clone, keeping the swarm active.

For any two swarm states $\mathcal{S}_1$ and $\mathcal{S}_2$ with $|\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S}_1)|=k_1 \ge 2$, the expected squared Euclidean distance between the sampled raw distance vectors is deterministically bounded by the function $F_{d,ms}$:

2739:

2742: $$
2743: 
2744: \boxed{

2746: }

3037: #### 11.1.5 Asymptotic Behavior of Moment Continuity
3038: The axiomatic structural growth exponents ($p_{\mu,S}, p_{m_2,S}$) of an aggregation operator determine the asymptotic behavior of the continuity for the derived statistical moments. The following theorem establishes how these base exponents propagate to the regularized standard deviation function, a critical step in analyzing the system's stability for large swarms.

3468: ### 11.3 Deterministic Lipschitz Continuity of the Patched Standardization Operator
3469: The introduction of the **Regularized Standard Deviation Function** ([](#def-statistical-properties-measurement)) ($\sigma\'_{\text{reg}}$) in Section 11.1.2 provides a critical stability guarantee that is stronger than mean-square continuity. By ensuring the denominator of the standardization formula is a globally Lipschitz function of the raw value variance, the pathological sensitivity near zero-variance states is eliminated. This, in turn, enables a deterministic, worst-case **global continuity with a Lipschitz–Hölder modulus** for the entire N-Dimensional Standardization Operator.
3470: This property is a non-negotiable prerequisite for certain powerful long-term convergence results, such as those derived from Feynman-Kac particle system theory. The following sections provide a rigorous, self-contained proof of this property. The strategy is to deterministically decompose the total error vector, $\Deltaz = z(S_1, v_1, M) - z(S_2, v_2, M)$, into a series of manageable components and to bound the L2-norm of each component by a term proportional to the N-Particle Displacement Metric and the L2-norm of the raw value difference.

4251: The **Status Update Operator ($Ψ_status$)** is a deterministic and inherently discontinuous function. Its effect on the system's stability can only be analyzed probabilistically by considering its composition with a stochastic position-update operator, such as the **Perturbation Operator ($Ψ_pert$)**. This section establishes the probabilistic continuity of this composed operator, $Ψ_status ∘ Ψ_pert$. It proves that the expected number of status changes between two output swarms is a Hölder-continuous function of the displacement between the input swarms. items.raw_directive:
4452: #### 15.2.3. Continuity of the Conditional Expected Cloning Action
4453: The overall cloning decision for a walker is stochastic due to the random choice of a companion. We can analyze the continuity of this process *conditional on a fixed fitness potential vector* by examining its expectation over the companion selection measure.
4454: :::{prf:definition} Conditional Expected Cloning Action
4455: :label: def-expected-cloning-action
4456: The **Conditional Expected Cloning Action** for a walker $i$, denoted $P_{\text{clone}}(\mathcal{S}, \mathbf{V})_i$, is the probability that walker $i$ will be assigned the "Clone" action, given the swarm state $\mathcal{S}$ and a specific, fixed fitness potential vector $\mathbf{V}$. It is the expectation of the **Conditional Cloning Probability Function** under the **Companion Selection Measure**:
4457: $$
4458: 
4459: P_{\text{clone}}(\mathcal{S}, \mathbf{V})_i := \mathbb{E}_{c \sim \mathbb{C}_i(\mathcal{S})} [\pi(V_c, V_i)]
4460: 
4461: $$
4462: :::
4463: :::{prf:theorem} Continuity of the Conditional Expected Cloning Action

4479: The proof decomposes the total error into a structural component and a value component using the triangle inequality:
4480: $|E_1[π_1] - E_2[π_2]| \leq |E_1[π_1] - E_1[π_2]| + |E_1[π_2] - E_2[π_2]|$.
4481: 1.  **Bound the Value Error Component:** The first term is the error from the change in potentials for a fixed companion measure. Using Jensen's inequality and the Lipschitz continuity of $\pi$ ([](#lem-cloning-probability-lipschitz)), this is bounded by $C_{val}^{(π)}$ times the sum of the expected companion potential change and the walker's own potential change.
4482: 2.  **Bound the Structural Error Component:** The second term is the error from the change in the companion measure for a fixed potential vector. We apply the **Total Error Bound in Terms of Status Changes ([](#thm-total-error-status-bound))**. The function being evaluated is bounded by $M_f=1$. The size of the initial companion set is at least $max(1, k_1-1)$. This gives the bound $C_{\text{struct}}^{(π)}(k_1) \cdot n_c$.
4483: Summing the two bounds gives the final result.
4484: **Q.E.D.**
4485: :::

items.label: thm-k1-revival-state
items.title: Theorem of Guaranteed Revival from a Single Survivor
items.content:
4694: **The Beautiful Result**: Under the right conditions, one survivor is enough to resurrect the entire swarm! This section proves that the "last walker standing" scenario triggers a guaranteed revival mechanism that brings all dead walkers back to life in a single step.
4695: 
4696: This is like having a "phoenix effect" built into the algorithm - the swarm can always rise from the ashes as long as one walker remains.
4697: :::
4698: The general continuity analysis presented in the preceding sections is valid for the regime where the number of alive walkers is at least two. The state where exactly one walker survives represents a critical boundary condition where the system's dynamics change fundamentally. This section provides a formal theorem to characterize the behavior in this "revival state," demonstrating how the foundational axioms ensure the swarm can recover from near-extinction events.

412: :label: thm-finite-n-mass-gap

414: There exists a critical coupling $\beta_c(N) > 0$ such that for all $\beta_{\text{gauge}} < \beta_c(N)$ (strong-coupling regime) and for all choices of parameters satisfying the conditions of {prf:ref}`thm-invariant-measure-existence`, the equilibrium state $\mu_{\text{inv}}$ describes a confining theory with a mass gap:

424:

426: \Delta_N \geq \delta

items.title: Existence of Continuum Limit
items.content:
434: :label: thm-continuum-limit
435: 
436: Consider a sequence of MDLGT systems indexed by $N$ with parameters chosen such that the average lattice spacing scales as:
437: 
438: $$
439: a_N \sim N^{-1/4}
440: 
441: $$
442: 
443: and the bare coupling runs according to:
444: 
445: $$
446: \beta_{\text{gauge}}(a_N) = \beta_{\text{gauge}}^{(0)} + b_0 \ln(a_N^{-1}) + O(1/\ln(a_N^{-1}))
447: 
448: $$
449: 
450: where $b_0 = \frac{11N_{\text{color}}}{3(4\pi)^2}$ is the one-loop beta function coefficient. Then:
451: 
452: 1. **Non-Triviality**: The limiting Schwinger functions (correlation functions of Wilson loops) exist and are non-trivial
453: 2. **Mass Gap Persistence**: The mass gap survives the continuum limit:
454: 
455: $$
456: \Delta := \lim_{N \to \infty} \Delta_N > 0
457: 
458: $$

items.title: Osterwalder-Schrader Axioms
items.content:
464: :label: thm-os-axioms
465: 
466: The continuum limit theory constructed in {prf:ref}`thm-continuum-limit` satisfies all Osterwalder-Schrader axioms:
467: 
468: 1. **OS1 (Euclidean Invariance)**: The Schwinger functions are invariant under the Euclidean group $E(4)$
469: 2. **OS2 (Reflection Positivity)**: The Schwinger functions satisfy reflection positivity with respect to time reflection
470: 3. **OS3 (Cluster Property)**: Correlation functions decay exponentially at large separations (consequence of mass gap)
471: 4. **OS4 (Regularity)**: The Schwinger functions have appropriate analyticity and growth properties

items.content:
1205: :label: thm-sasaki-distance-ms
1206: 
1207: Let $\mathbf d^{(r)}$ be the expected raw distance vectors of swarms $\mathcal S_r$. With $k_{\min}:=\max\{1,\min(k_1,k_2)\}$, $k_{\mathrm{stable}}:=|\mathcal A_{\mathrm{stable}}|$, and alive-difference count $n_c:=\sum_{i=1}^N(s_{1,i}-s_{2,i})^2$, define
1208: 
1209: $$
1210: F_{d,ms}^{\mathrm{Sasaki}}(\Delta_{\mathrm{pos}}^2,n_c):=C_{\mathrm{pos}}^{\mathrm{Sasaki}}(k_1,k_{\mathrm{stable}})\,\Delta_{\mathrm{pos}}^2+4k_{\mathrm{stable}}\frac{D_{\mathcal Y}^2}{\max\{1,k_1-1\}^2}\,n_c^2+4D_{\mathcal Y}^2 n_c.
1211: 
1212: $$
1213: 
1214: Referenced by {prf:ref}`thm-euclidean-feller`.
1215: 
1216: Then
1217: 
1218: $$
1219: \big\|\mathbf d^{(1)}-\mathbf d^{(2)}\big\|_2^2\le F_{d,ms}^{\mathrm{Sasaki}}\big(\Delta_{\mathrm{pos,Sasaki}}^2(\mathcal S_1,\mathcal S_2),n_c(\mathcal S_1,\mathcal S_2)\big).
1220: 
1221: $$
1222: 
1223: ```{dropdown} Proof
1224: :::{prf:proof}
1225: Decompose the index set into stable walkers $\mathcal A_{\mathrm{stable}}$ and the complement. For stable walkers the bound in Lemma {prf:ref}`lem-sasaki-total-squared-error-stable` applies. For walkers whose status changes between the two swarms we use $|d^{(1)}_i-d^{(2)}_i|\le D_{\mathcal Y}$ because each expected distance is bounded by the diameter of the Sasaki algorithmic space. There are at most $2n_c$ such indices, contributing at most $4D_{\mathcal Y}^2n_c$ to the squared error.

items.label: lem-sasaki-standardization-lipschitz
items.title: Composite Continuity of the Patched Standardization Operator (Sasaki)
items.content:
2004: :label: thm-sasaki-standardization-composite-sq
2005: 
2006: The N-dimensional standardization operator $z(\mathcal S)$, when applied to the reward vector, is continuous with respect to the dispersion metric. For any two swarms $\mathcal S_1, \mathcal S_2$ with $k_1=|\mathcal A(\mathcal S_1)|\ge 1$, the squared L2-norm of the output error is bounded by a composite function of the squared dispersion distance:
2007: 
2008: $$
2009: \|z(\mathcal S_1)-z(\mathcal S_2)\|_2^2 \le L_{z,L}^2(\mathcal S_1,\mathcal S_2) \cdot d_{\mathrm{Disp},\mathcal Y}^{\mathrm{Sasaki}}(\mathcal S_1, \mathcal S_2)^2 + L_{z,H}^2(\mathcal S_1,\mathcal S_2) \cdot d_{\mathrm{Disp},\mathcal Y}^{\mathrm{Sasaki}}(\mathcal S_1, \mathcal S_2)^4
2010: 
2011: $$
2012: 
2013: where $L_{z,L}^2$ and $L_{z,H}^2$ are state-dependent coefficients representing the Lipschitz and higher-order parts of the bound, respectively. Consequently, the logistic rescale operator $u(\mathcal S) = g_A(z(\mathcal S))$ is also continuous.
2014: 
2015: ```{dropdown} Proof
2016: :::{prf:proof}
2017: The proof establishes a deterministic bound on the total error $\|z(\mathcal S_1, \mathbf r_1) - z(\mathcal S_2, \mathbf r_2)\|_2^2$ by combining the bounds for value-induced error and structure-induced error.
2018: 
2019: **Step 1: Decomposing the Total Error.**
2020: Let $\mathbf r_1$ and $\mathbf r_2$ be the raw reward vectors for swarms $\mathcal S_1$ and $\mathcal S_2$. We introduce an intermediate vector $z(\mathcal S_1, \mathbf r_2)$ and use the inequality $\|A-C\|_2^2 \le 2(\|A-B\|_2^2 + \|B-C\|_2^2)$. The total squared error is bounded by the sum of a pure value error component and a pure structural error component:
2021: 
2022: $$
2023: \|z(\mathcal S_1, \mathbf r_1) - z(\mathcal S_2, \mathbf r_2)\|_2^2 \le 2\,\|\underbrace{z(\mathcal S_1, \mathbf r_1) - z(\mathcal S_1, \mathbf r_2)}_{E_V}\|_2^2 + 2\,\|\underbrace{z(\mathcal S_1, \mathbf r_2) - z(\mathcal S_2, \mathbf r_2)}_{E_S}\|_2^2
2024: 
2025: $$
2026: 
2027: **Step 2: Bounding the Squared Value Error Term (`||E_V||_2^2`).**
2028: The first term is a pure value error for the fixed swarm structure $\mathcal S_1$. We apply Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-sasaki-standardization-value`:
2029: 
2030: $$
2031: \|E_V\|_2^2 \le C_{V,\mathrm{total}}^{\mathrm{Sasaki}}(\mathcal S_1) \cdot \|\mathbf r_1 - \mathbf r_2\|_2^2
2032: 
2033: $$
2034: The squared difference of the raw reward vectors is bounded by the sum of contributions from walkers with stable status and unstable status:
2035: 
2036: $$
2037: \|\mathbf r_1 - \mathbf r_2\|_2^2 = \sum_{i \in \mathcal A_1 \cap \mathcal A_2} |r_{1,i}-r_{2,i}|^2 + \sum_{i \in \mathcal A_1 \triangle \mathcal A_2} |r_{1,i}-r_{2,i}|^2 \le (L_R^{\mathrm{Sasaki}})^2 \Delta_{\mathrm{pos,Sasaki}}^2 + n_c (2 V_{\max}^{(R)})^2
2038: 
2039: $$
2040: where we used that for unstable walkers, one reward is zero and the other is bounded by $V_{\max}^{(R)}$.
2041: 
2042: **Step 3: Bounding the Squared Structural Error Term (`||E_S||_2^2`).**
2043: The second term is a pure structural error for the fixed raw value vector $\mathbf r_2$. We apply Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-sasaki-standardization-structural-sq`:
2044: 
2045: $$
2046: \|E_S\|_2^2 \le C_{S,\mathrm{direct}}^{\mathrm{sq}} \cdot n_c + C_{S,\mathrm{indirect}}^{\mathrm{sq}}(\mathcal S_1, \mathcal S_2) \cdot n_c^2
2047: 
2048: $$
2049:

2063: 
2064: $$

2070: 
2071: $$
2072: 
2073: The coefficients are explicit:

2075: $$

2080: 
2081: $$

2056: $$

2064: $$

2071: $$

items.label: thm-euclidean-feller
items.title: Feller continuity of $\Psi_{\mathcal F_{\mathrm{EG}}}$
items.content:
2309: :label: thm-euclidean-feller
2310: 
2311: ```{dropdown} Proof
2312: :::{prf:proof}
2313: Write the single-step operator as the composition of the cemetery check (Stage 1), the measurement and potential pipeline (Stage 2), the Clone/Persist gate (Stage 3), and the kinetic-plus-status update (Stage 4). Each stage defines a Markov kernel on $\Sigma_N$ that is Feller with respect to $d_{\mathrm{Disp},\mathcal Y}^{\mathrm{Sasaki}}$; the claim follows because Feller kernels are closed under composition (see, e.g., \[Ethier & Kurtz 86, Prop. 4.2.2\]).
2314: 
2315: 1. **Stage 1 (cemetery absorption).** The map $\mathcal S\mapsto\delta_{\mathcal S}$ is continuous. The absorbing branch fires only when $\mathcal A(\mathcal S)=\varnothing$, which is a closed condition, so Stage 1 is Feller.
2316: 
2317: 2. **Stage 2 (measurement and potential pipeline).** Conditional on $\mathcal S$, the companion draws $(c_{\mathrm{pot}}(i))$ are sampled from the product coupling $\mathbb C(\mathcal S)$, which depends continuously on $\mathcal S$ in the dispersion metric by Lemma {prf:ref}`lem-sasaki-single-walker-positional-error`. Lemma {prf:ref}`thm-sasaki-distance-ms` bounds the mean-square variation of the companion distances, and Lemma {prf:ref}`lem-sasaki-aggregator-lipschitz` together with Theorems {prf:ref}`thm-sasaki-standardization-value` and {prf:ref}`thm-sasaki-standardization-structural` show that the patched standardisation and logistic rescale operators depend continuously on the raw values. Consequently the kernel that outputs $(\mathbf r,\mathbf d,\mathbf V_{\text{fit}})$ is Feller.
2318: 
2319: 3. **Stage 3 (Clone/Persist gate).** The Bernoulli probabilities $p_i(\mathcal S)$ governing the Clone/Persist decision are continuous functions of the standardized scores produced in Stage 2. Conditional on cloning, the jitter distribution is Gaussian with fixed covariance; the resulting pushforward through the 1-Lipschitz squashing map $\psi_v$ is Feller by Lemma {prf:ref}`lem-squashing-properties-generic`. Therefore the Stage-3 kernel is a finite mixture of Feller kernels with continuous weights and is itself Feller.
2320: 
2321: 4. **Stage 4 (kinetic step and boundary check).** Lemma {prf:ref}`lem-euclidean-perturb-moment` proves that the capped kinetic update map $(x,v)\mapsto(x^+,v^+)$ is Feller and that its second moment grows at most quadratically in the state norm. The status indicator is applied to $x^+$; Lemma {prf:ref}`lem-euclidean-boundary-holder` shows that the death probability varies continuously and that $\mathbb P(x^+\in\partial\mathcal X_{\mathrm{valid}})=0$ under the $C^1$-boundary assumption, so the indicator preserves the Feller property.
2322:

items.title: Derivation of the Stability Condition for Intelligent Adaptation
items.content:
3951: :label: thm-derivation-of-stability-condition
3952: 
3953: Let the system satisfy the foundational axioms, including the **Axiom of Non-Deceptive Landscapes (EG-7)**. Let a swarm `k` have a sufficiently large internal positional variance, $\mathrm{Var}_x(S_k) > R^2_{\mathrm{var}}$.
3954: 
3955: The algorithm's targeting mechanism is "intelligent" (i.e., the expected fitness of a high-error walker is systematically lower than that of a low-error walker) if and only if the system parameters ($\alpha$, $\beta$, $\varepsilon$, etc.) satisfy the following **Stability Condition**:
3956: 
3957: $$
3958: \beta \ln\left(1 + \frac{\kappa_{\text{mean},d'}(\epsilon)}{g_{A,max}+\eta}\right) > \alpha \ln\left(1 + \frac{\kappa_{\text{mean},r'}}{\eta}\right)
3959: $$
items.section: ## 7. The Corrective Nature of Fitness: From Signal Generation to Intelligent Adaptation
items.raw_directive:
3948: This property is not unconditional. We will rigorously derive a **Stability Condition** on the algorithm's dynamics parameters ($\alpha$, $\beta$, $\varepsilon$) from first principles. The proof will be statistical in nature, analyzing the expected fitness of the entire "high-error" population versus the "low-error" population. We will demonstrate that satisfying this Stability Condition is the necessary and sufficient condition to guarantee that the high-error walkers are, on average, less fit. This derivation provides the formal justification for elevating this condition to the status of a foundational axiom for any well-posed Fragile Gas system.

items.content:
6223: :label: thm-cloning-operator-composition
6224: 
6225: The cloning operator admits the following compositional representation:
6226: 
6227: $$
6228: \Psi_{\text{clone}}(S, \cdot) = \int_{\mathbf{d}} \int_{\mathbf{c}, \mathbf{a}} \Psi_{\text{update}}(S, \mathbf{c}, \mathbf{a}, \cdot) \, dP_{\text{decision}}(S, \mathbf{V}_{\text{fit}}(\mathbf{d}), \mathbf{c}, \mathbf{a}) \, dP_{\text{measure}}(S, \mathbf{d})
6229: $$
6230: 
6231: where:
6232: - $P_{\text{measure}}(S, \cdot)$ is the distribution of raw distance vectors from $\Psi_{\text{measure}}$
6233: - $\mathbf{V}_{\text{fit}}(\mathbf{d})$ is the deterministic fitness vector from $\Psi_{\text{fitness}}$ given $S$ and $\mathbf{d}$
6234: - $P_{\text{decision}}(S, \mathbf{V}_{\text{fit}}, \cdot)$ is the joint distribution of companion assignments and actions
6235: - $\Psi_{\text{update}}(S, \mathbf{c}, \mathbf{a}, \cdot)$ is the (possibly stochastic) output distribution given the actions
6236: 
6237: This composition is a proper Markov kernel: for any measurable set $A \subseteq \Sigma_N$,
6238: 
6239: $$
6240: \Psi_{\text{clone}}(S, A) = P(S' \in A \mid S)
6241: $$
6242: 
6243: is a well-defined probability.
items.raw_directive:
6220: We now assemble the complete operator from its components.
6221: 
6222: :::{prf:theorem} Compositional Structure of $\Psi_{\text{clone}}$
6223: :label: thm-cloning-operator-composition
6224: 
6225: The cloning operator admits the following compositional representation:
6226: 
6227: $$
6228: \Psi_{\text{clone}}(S, \cdot) = \int_{\mathbf{d}} \int_{\mathbf{c}, \mathbf{a}} \Psi_{\text{update}}(S, \mathbf{c}, \mathbf{a}, \cdot) \, dP_{\text{decision}}(S, \mathbf{V}_{\text{fit}}(\mathbf{d}), \mathbf{c}, \mathbf{a}) \, dP_{\text{measure}}(S, \mathbf{d})
6229: $$
6230: 
6231: where:
6232: - $P_{\text{measure}}(S, \cdot)$ is the distribution of raw distance vectors from $\Psi_{\text{measure}}$
6233: - $\mathbf{V}_{\text{fit}}(\mathbf{d})$ is the deterministic fitness vector from $\Psi_{\text{fitness}}$ given $S$ and $\mathbf{d}$
6234: - $P_{\text{decision}}(S, \mathbf{V}_{\text{fit}}, \cdot)$ is the joint distribution of companion assignments and actions
6235: - $\Psi_{\text{update}}(S, \mathbf{c}, \mathbf{a}, \cdot)$ is the (possibly stochastic) output distribution given the actions
6236: 
6237: This composition is a proper Markov kernel: for any measurable set $A \subseteq \Sigma_N$,
6238: 
6239: $$
6240: \Psi_{\text{clone}}(S, A) = P(S' \in A \mid S)
6241: $$
6242: 
6243: is a well-defined probability.

items.content:
6942: :label: thm-complete-variance-drift
6943: 
6944: The cloning operator $\Psi_{\text{clone}}$ induces the following drift on the variance components of the Lyapunov function:
6945: 
6946: **1. Positional Variance (Strong Contraction):**
6947: 
6948: $$
6949: \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},x}] \leq -\kappa_x V_{\text{Var},x} + C_x
6950: $$
6951: 
6952: where $\kappa_x > 0$ is $N$-independent (from Keystone Principle).
6953: 
6954: **2. Velocity Variance (Bounded Expansion):**
6955: 
6956: $$
6957: \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},v}] \leq C_v
6958: $$
6959: 
6960: where $C_v < \infty$ is a state-independent constant.
6961:

6963: 
6964: $$
6965: \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta V_{\text{Var}}] = \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},x}] + \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},v}] \leq -\kappa_x V_{\text{Var},x} + (C_x + C_v)
6966: $$

items.title: Complete Boundary Potential Drift Characterization
items.content:
7783: :label: thm-complete-boundary-drift
7784: 
7785: The cloning operator $\Psi_{\text{clone}}$ induces the following drift on the boundary potential:
7786: 
7787: $$
7788: \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta W_b] \leq -\kappa_b W_b + C_b
7789: $$
7790: 
7791: where:
7792: - $\kappa_b = p_{\text{boundary}}(\phi_{\text{thresh}}) > 0$ is the minimum cloning probability for boundary-exposed walkers
7793: - $C_b = O(\sigma_x^2 + N^{-1})$ accounts for position jitter and dead walker revival
7794: - Both constants are **$N$-independent** in the large-$N$ limit
7795: 
7796: **Key Properties:**
7797: 
7798: 1. **Unconditional contraction:** The drift is negative for all states with $W_b > C_b/\kappa_b$
7799: 
7800: 2. **Strengthening near danger:** The contraction rate $\kappa_b$ increases with boundary proximity (through $\phi_{\text{thresh}}$)

items.label: thm-complete-wasserstein-drift
items.title: Complete Wasserstein Decomposition Drift
items.content:
8053: :label: thm-complete-wasserstein-drift
8054: 
8055: The total inter-swarm Wasserstein distance $V_W = V_{\text{loc}} + V_{\text{struct}}$ satisfies a combined drift inequality under the cloning operator:
8056: 
8057: $$
8058: \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta V_W] \leq C_W
8059: $$
8060: 
8061: where $C_W < \infty$ is a state-independent constant satisfying:
8062: 
8063: $$
8064: C_W = C_{\text{loc}} + C_{\text{struct}}
8065: $$
8066: 
8067: **Component Bounds:**
8068: 
8069: From {prf:ref}`cor-component-bounds-vw`, the individual components satisfy:
8070: 
8071: $$
8072: \begin{aligned}
8073: \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta V_{\text{loc}}] &\leq C_{\text{loc}} \\
8074: \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta V_{\text{struct}}] &\leq C_{\text{struct}}
8075: \end{aligned}
8076: $$
8077: 
8078: where:
8079: - $C_{\text{loc}}$ arises from barycenter desynchronization due to differential cloning rates
8080: - $C_{\text{struct}}$ arises from jitter noise and structural rearrangement during cloning
8081: 
8082: **Note on Kinetic Contraction:**
8083: 
8084: While the cloning operator allows bounded expansion of $V_W$, the **kinetic operator** provides contraction. From hypocoercive analysis (Chapter 4 of companion document):
8085: 
8086: $$
8087: \mathbb{E}_{\text{kin}}[\Delta V_W] \leq -\kappa_W^{\text{kin}} \tau V_W + C_W^{\text{kin}} \tau
8088: $$

items.label: thm-complete-cloning-drift
items.title: Complete Drift Inequality for the Cloning Operator
items.content:
8145: :label: thm-complete-cloning-drift
8146: 
8147: Under the foundational axioms (Chapter 4), the cloning operator $\Psi_{\text{clone}}$ (see {prf:ref}`def-cloning-operator-formal`) induces the following drift on the synergistic Lyapunov function:
8148: 
8149: $$
8150: V_{\text{total}}(S_1, S_2) = V_W(S_1, S_2) + c_V V_{\text{Var}}(S_1, S_2) + c_B W_b(S_1, S_2)
8151: $$
8152: 
8153: **Individual Component Drifts:**
8154: 
8155: $$
8156: \begin{aligned}
8157: \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta V_W] &\leq C_W \quad &\text{(bounded expansion)} \\
8158: \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},x}] &\leq -\kappa_x V_{\text{Var},x} + C_x \quad &\text{(strong contraction)} \\
8159: \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},v}] &\leq C_v \quad &\text{(bounded expansion)} \\
8160: \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta W_b] &\leq -\kappa_b W_b + C_b \quad &\text{(strong contraction)}
8161: \end{aligned}
8162: $$
8163: 
8164: **Combined Drift:**
8165: 
8166: $$
8167: \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta V_{\text{total}}] \leq C_W + c_V(-\kappa_x V_{\text{Var},x} + C_v + C_x) + c_B(-\kappa_b W_b + C_b)
8168: $$
8169: 
8170: **Critical Property - Partial Contraction:**
8171: 
8172: When $V_{\text{Var},x}$ and $W_b$ are sufficiently large relative to the expansion terms, the drift becomes negative:
8173: 
8174: $$
8175: \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta V_{\text{total}}] < 0 \quad \text{when } c_V V_{\text{Var},x} + c_B W_b > \frac{C_W + c_V(C_v + C_x) + c_B C_b}{\min(\kappa_x, \kappa_b)}

items.content:
8460: :label: thm-main-results-summary
8461: 
8462: This document has established the following results for the cloning operator $\Psi_{\text{clone}}$:
8463: 
8464: **1. The Keystone Principle (Chapters 5-8):**
8465: - Large internal positional variance → detectable geometric structure
8466: - Geometric structure → reliable fitness signal (N-uniform)
8467: - Fitness signal → corrective cloning pressure
8468: - **Result:** $\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i \in I_{11}} (p_{1,i} + p_{2,i})\|\Delta\delta_{x,i}\|^2 \geq \chi(\epsilon) V_{\text{struct}} - g_{\max}(\epsilon)$
8469: 
8470: **2. Positional Variance Contraction (Chapter 10):**
8471: - The Keystone Principle translates to rigorous drift inequality

858: :label: thm-cg-gauge-theory-emergence-main
859: 
860: The Crystalline Gas algorithm ({prf:ref}`def-cg-dynamics`) with fitness landscape satisfying {prf:ref}`def-cg-fitness-landscape` naturally generates a pure SU(3)_c × SU(2)_L × U(1)_Y Yang-Mills theory at equilibrium through the following mappings:
861: 
862: | **Algorithmic Structure** | **Gauge Theory Interpretation** | **Mathematical Construction** |
863: |---------------------------|--------------------------------|-------------------------------|
864: | Force-momentum tensor $F \otimes p$ | 8 gluon fields (SU(3)_c) | $A_{\mu}^a = \partial_{\mu} \varphi^a$ where $(F \otimes p)_{\text{traceless}} = \sum_a \varphi^a \lambda^a$ |
865: | Companion direction $\hat{r}$ | 3 weak bosons (SU(2)_L) | $W_{\mu}^a = \partial_{\mu}(S_{\text{ascent}} \cdot \hat{r}^a)$ |

870: | QSD equilibrium | Pure gauge vacuum | $\langle J_{\mu} \rangle_{\text{QSD}} = 0$ |
871: 
872: The construction is:
873: - **Mathematically rigorous:** Every gauge field is explicitly defined from algorithmic quantities

items.label: thm-main-contraction-summary
items.title: Wasserstein-2 Contraction (Main Theorem)
items.content:
21: :label: thm-main-contraction-summary
22: 
23: Let $\mu_1, \mu_2$ be two empirical swarm distributions over $N$ walkers in state space $\mathcal{X} = \mathbb{R}^d$. Suppose:
24: 1. Both swarms satisfy the Fragile Gas axioms (Confining Potential, Environmental Richness, Bounded Virtual Rewards)
25: 2. The swarms have separation $L := \|\bar{x}_1 - \bar{x}_2\| > L_0(\delta, \varepsilon)$, where $L_0$ is the separation threshold
26: 
27: Then, applying the cloning operator contracts the Wasserstein-2 distance:
28: 
29: $$
30: W_2^2(\Psi_{\text{clone}}(\mu_1), \Psi_{\text{clone}}(\mu_2)) \leq (1 - \kappa_W) W_2^2(\mu_1, \mu_2) + C_W
31: $$
32: 
33: where:
34: - **Contraction constant** (N-uniform):
35:   $$
36:   \kappa_W = \frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{p_u \eta_{\text{geo}}}{2} \cdot f_{UH}(\varepsilon) \cdot q_{\min}(\varepsilon) > 0
37:   $$
38: 
39: - **Noise constant**:
40:   $$
41:   C_W = 4d\delta^2
42:   $$
43: 
44: - **Separation threshold**:
45:   $$
46:   L_0 = \max\left(D_{\min}, \frac{2\sqrt{d}\delta}{\sqrt{\kappa_B f_{UH} q_{\min}}}\right)
47:   $$

items.label: thm-single-pair-contraction
items.title: Single-Pair Expected Contraction
items.content:
1769: :label: thm-single-pair-contraction
1770: 
1771: For a matched pair $(i, \pi(i))$ drawn from the synchronous coupling matching distribution $M$ for swarms $S_1$, $S_2$ with separation $L > D_{\min}$, the expected post-cloning squared distance satisfies:
1772: 
1773: $$
1774: \mathbb{E}[D'_{i\pi(i)} \mid M, T] \leq (1 - \kappa_{\text{pair}}) D_{i\pi(i)} + C_W
1775: $$
1776: 
1777: where:
1778: $$
1779: \kappa_{\text{pair}} := \mathbb{P}(\text{Case B} \mid M) \cdot \kappa_B - \mathbb{P}(\text{Case A} \mid M) \cdot \varepsilon_A
1780: $$
1781: 
1782: with:
1783: - $\kappa_B = \frac{p_u \eta_{\text{geo}}}{2}$ (Case B contraction constant)
1784: - $\varepsilon_A = \frac{4d\delta^2}{L^2}$ (Case A expansion rate, vanishes for large $L$)
1785: - $\mathbb{P}(\text{Case B} \mid M) \geq f_{UH}(\varepsilon) \cdot q_{\min}(\varepsilon) > 0$ (from Lemma 4.6)
1786: - $\mathbb{P}(\text{Case A} \mid M) \leq 1 - f_{UH}(\varepsilon) \cdot q_{\min}(\varepsilon)$
1787: 
1788: **N-Uniformity**: For sufficiently large separation $L > L_{\min}(\varepsilon)$ where $\varepsilon_A < \frac{\kappa_B}{2}$, we have:
1789: 
1790: $$
1791: \kappa_{\text{pair}} \geq \frac{\kappa_B f_{UH}(\varepsilon) q_{\min}(\varepsilon)}{2} > 0
1792: $$

items.content:
1413: :label: thm-inter-swarm-contraction-kinetic
1414: 
1415: Under the axioms of Chapter 3, there exist constants $\kappa_W > 0$, $C_W' < \infty$, and hypocoercive parameters $(\lambda_v, b)$, all independent of $N$, such that:
1416: 
1417: $$
1418: \mathbb{E}_{\text{kin}}[V_W(S'_1, S'_2) \mid S_1, S_2] \leq (1 - \kappa_W \tau) V_W(S_1, S_2) + C_W' \tau
1419: 
1420: $$
1421: 
1422: where $\tau$ is the timestep and $S'_1, S'_2$ are the outputs after the kinetic evolution.
1423: 
1424: **Equivalently (one-step drift):**
1425: 
1426: $$
1427: \mathbb{E}_{\text{kin}}[\Delta V_W] \leq -\kappa_W V_W + C_W'
1428: 
1429: $$
1430: 
1431: **Key Properties:**
1432: 
1433: 1. **Contraction rate** $\kappa_W$ scales as:
1434:    
1435: $$
1436: \kappa_W \sim \min(\gamma, \alpha_U, \sigma_{\min}^2)
1437: 
1438: $$
1439:    where $\gamma$ is friction, $\alpha_U$ is the confinement strength, and $\sigma_{\min}^2$ is the minimum diffusion eigenvalue.
1440: 
1441: 2. **Expansion bound** $C_W'$ accounts for:
1442:    - Bounded noise injection ($\sim \sigma_{\max}^2$)
1443:    - Status changes (deaths creating divergence)
1444:    - Boundary effects

items.content:
841: :label: thm-aperiodicity
842: 
843: The Euclidean Gas Markov chain is **aperiodic**: For any state $S \in \Sigma_N^{\text{alive}}$ and any open set $U$ containing $S$, there exist integers $m, n$ with $\gcd(m,n) = 1$ such that:
844: 
845: $$
846: P^m(S, U) > 0 \quad \text{and} \quad P^n(S, U) > 0
847: $$

items.label: thm-main-convergence
items.title: Geometric Ergodicity and Convergence to QSD
items.content:
913: :label: thm-main-convergence
914: 
915: Under the foundational axioms (03_cloning.md Ch 4, this document Ch 1), the Euclidean Gas Markov chain satisfies:
916: 
917: **1. Existence and Uniqueness of QSD:**
918: 
919: There exists a unique quasi-stationary distribution $\nu_{\text{QSD}}$ on $\Sigma_N^{\text{alive}}$.
920: 
921: **2. Exponential Convergence to QSD:**
922: 
923: For any initial distribution $\mu_0$ on $\Sigma_N^{\text{alive}}$ and for all $t \geq 0$:
924: 
925: $$
926: \|\mu_t - \nu_{\text{QSD}}\|_{\text{TV}} \leq C_{\text{conv}} e^{-\kappa_{\text{QSD}} t}
927: $$
928: 
929: where:
930: - $\|\cdot\|_{\text{TV}}$ is the total variation distance
931: - $\kappa_{\text{QSD}} = \Theta(\kappa_{\text{total}}\tau) > 0$ is the convergence rate
932: - $C_{\text{conv}}$ depends on $\mu_0$ and $V_{\text{total}}(S_0)$
933: 
934: **3. Exponentially Long Survival Time:**
935: 
936: Starting from $\nu_{\text{QSD}}$, the expected time until absorption satisfies:
937: 
938: $$
939: \mathbb{E}_{\nu_{\text{QSD}}}[\tau_{\dagger}] = e^{\Theta(N)}
940: $$
941: 
942: The survival time grows **exponentially with $N$**.
943: 
944: **4. Concentration Around QSD:**
945: 
946: For any $\epsilon > 0$, there exists $N_0(\epsilon)$ such that for $N > N_0$:
947: 
948: $$
949: P(V_{\text{total}}(S_t) > (1+\epsilon) V_{\text{total}}^{\text{QSD}} \mid \text{survived to time } t) \leq e^{-\Theta(N)}
950: $$

items.label: thm-equilibrium-variance-bounds
items.title: Equilibrium Variance Bounds from Drift Inequalities
items.content:
1064: :label: thm-equilibrium-variance-bounds
1065: 
1066: The quasi-stationary distribution satisfies explicit variance bounds derived from the component drift inequalities:
1067: 
1068: **Positional Variance Equilibrium:**
1069: 
1070: From {prf:ref}`thm-positional-variance-contraction` (cloning contraction) and kinetic drift, setting $\mathbb{E}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},x}] = 0$ yields:
1071: 
1072: $$
1073: V_{\text{Var},x}^{\text{QSD}} \leq \frac{C_x}{\kappa_x}
1074: $$
1075: 
1076: where:
1077: - $\kappa_x > 0$ is the N-uniform positional contraction rate from the Keystone Principle
1078: - $C_x < \infty$ is the additive expansion constant from cloning noise and boundary effects
1079: 
1080: **Velocity Variance Equilibrium:**
1081: 
1082: From {prf:ref}`thm-bounded-velocity-expansion-cloning` (cloning expansion) and {prf:ref}`thm-velocity-variance-contraction-kinetic` (Langevin friction), setting $\mathbb{E}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},v}] = 0$ yields:
1083: 
1084: $$
1085: V_{\text{Var},v}^{\text{QSD}} \leq \frac{C_v + \sigma_{\max}^2 d \tau}{2\gamma\tau}
1086: $$
1087: 
1088: where:
1089: - $C_v$ is the state-independent velocity expansion from inelastic collisions
1090: - $\sigma_{\max}^2 d \tau$ is the noise injection from Langevin dynamics
1091: - $2\gamma\tau$ is the friction dissipation rate
1092: 
1093: **Simplified form** (when $C_v \ll \sigma_{\max}^2 d \tau$):
1094: 
1095: $$
1096: V_{\text{Var},v}^{\text{QSD}} \approx \frac{d\sigma_{\max}^2}{2\gamma}
1097: $$
1098: 
1099: recovering the classical equipartition result.
1100: 
1101: **Boundary Potential Equilibrium:**
1102: 
1103: From {prf:ref}`thm-boundary-potential-contraction`, setting $\mathbb{E}[\Delta W_b] = 0$ yields:
1104: 
1105: $$
1106: W_b^{\text{QSD}} \leq \frac{C_b}{\kappa_b}
1107: $$
1108: 
1109: ensuring bounded boundary exposure in the QSD.
1110: 
1111: **Physical Interpretation:**
1112: 
1113: These bounds show that equilibrium variance is determined by the balance between:
1114: - **Contraction mechanisms**: Cloning (positional), friction (velocity), Safe Harbor (boundary)
1115: - **Expansion mechanisms**: Cloning noise, Langevin noise, boundary reentry

items.label: thm-synergistic-rate-derivation
items.title: Synergistic Rate Derivation from Component Drifts
items.content:
1632: :label: thm-synergistic-rate-derivation
1633: 
1634: The total drift inequality combines component-wise drift bounds from cloning and kinetic operators to yield explicit synergistic convergence.
1635: 
1636: **Component Drift Structure:**
1637: 
1638: From the cloning operator {prf:ref}`thm-positional-variance-contraction` and kinetic operator {prf:ref}`thm-velocity-variance-contraction`, each Lyapunov component satisfies:
1639: 
1640: $$
1641: \begin{aligned}
1642: \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},x}] &\leq -\kappa_x V_{\text{Var},x} + C_x + C_{xv} V_{\text{Var},v} + C_{xW} V_W \\
1643: \mathbb{E}_{\text{kin}}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},v}] &\leq -\kappa_v V_{\text{Var},v} + C_v + C_{vx} V_{\text{Var},x} \\
1644: \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta V_W] &\leq -\kappa_W V_W + C_W \\
1645: \mathbb{E}_{\text{clone}}[\Delta W_b] &\leq -\kappa_b W_b + C_b
1646: \end{aligned}
1647: $$
1648: 
1649: where cross-component coupling terms $C_{xv}, C_{xW}, C_{vx}$ arise from expansion by the complementary operator.
1650: 
1651: **Weighted Combination:**
1652: 
1653: Define the weighted Lyapunov function:
1654: 
1655: $$
1656: V_{\text{total}} = V_{\text{Var},x} + \alpha_v V_{\text{Var},v} + \alpha_W V_W + \alpha_b W_b
1657: $$
1658: 
1659: Taking expectations over a full step (kinetic + cloning):
1660: 
1661: $$
1662: \begin{aligned}
1663: \mathbb{E}[\Delta V_{\text{total}}] &= \mathbb{E}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},x}] + \alpha_v \mathbb{E}[\Delta V_{\text{Var},v}] + \alpha_W \mathbb{E}[\Delta V_W] + \alpha_b \mathbb{E}[\Delta W_b] \\
1664: &\leq (-\kappa_x V_{\text{Var},x} + C_x + C_{xv} V_{\text{Var},v} + C_{xW} V_W) \\
1665: &\quad + \alpha_v(-\kappa_v V_{\text{Var},v} + C_v + C_{vx} V_{\text{Var},x}) \\
1666: &\quad + \alpha_W(-\kappa_W V_W + C_W) \\
1667: &\quad + \alpha_b(-\kappa_b W_b + C_b)
1668: \end{aligned}
1669: $$
1670: 
1671: **Weight Selection for Coupling Domination:**
1672: 
1673: Choose weights to ensure coupling terms are dominated by contraction:
1674: 
1675: $$
1676: \alpha_v \geq \frac{C_{xv}}{\kappa_v V_{\text{Var},v}^{\text{eq}}}, \quad
1677: \alpha_W \geq \frac{C_{xW}}{\kappa_W V_W^{\text{eq}}}, \quad
1678: \alpha_v \kappa_v \geq C_{vx} / V_{\text{Var},x}^{\text{eq}}
1679: $$
1680: 
1681: With these weights, the coupling terms satisfy:
1682: 
1683: $$
1684: C_{xv} V_{\text{Var},v} - \alpha_v \kappa_v V_{\text{Var},v} \leq -\epsilon_v \alpha_v \kappa_v V_{\text{Var},v}
1685: $$
1686: 
1687: and similarly for other cross terms, where $\epsilon_v, \epsilon_W \ll 1$ are small positive fractions.
1688: 
1689: **Synergistic Rate:**
1690: 
1691: After cancellation of dominated coupling terms:
1692: 
1693: $$
1694: \mathbb{E}[\Delta V_{\text{total}}] \leq -\kappa_{\text{total}} V_{\text{total}} + C_{\text{total}}
1695: $$
1696: 
1697: where:
1698: 
1699: $$
1700: \kappa_{\text{total}} = \min(\kappa_x, \alpha_v \kappa_v, \alpha_W \kappa_W, \alpha_b \kappa_b) \cdot (1 - \epsilon_{\text{coupling}})
1701: $$
1702: 
1703: $$
1704: C_{\text{total}} = C_x + \alpha_v C_v + \alpha_W C_W + \alpha_b C_b
1705: $$
1706: 
1707: and $\epsilon_{\text{coupling}} = \max(\epsilon_v, \epsilon_W, \ldots)$ is the residual coupling ratio after weight balancing.
1708: 
1709: **Physical Interpretation:**
1710: 
1711: The synergistic rate $\kappa_{\text{total}}$ is determined by:
1712: 1. **Bottleneck principle**: The weakest contraction rate dominates (min over components)
1713: 2. **Coupling penalty**: $\epsilon_{\text{coupling}}$ reduces the effective rate due to energy transfer between components
1714: 3. **Weight balancing**: Optimal $\alpha_i$ maximize $\alpha_i \kappa_i$ subject to coupling domination
1715: 
1716: When $\epsilon_{\text{coupling}} \ll 1$, the total rate approaches the bottleneck component rate. The equilibrium variance is:
1717: 
1718: $$
1719: V_{\text{total}}^{\text{QSD}} = \frac{C_{\text{total}}}{\kappa_{\text{total}}}
1720: $$

items.title: Total Convergence Rate (Parameter-Explicit)
items.content:
1743: :label: thm-total-rate-explicit
1744: 
1745: The total geometric convergence rate is:
1746: 
1747: $$
1748: \kappa_{\text{total}} = \min(\kappa_x, \kappa_v, \kappa_W, \kappa_b) \cdot (1 - \epsilon_{\text{coupling}})
1749: $$
1750: 
1751: where $\epsilon_{\text{coupling}} \ll 1$ is the expansion-to-contraction ratio:
1752: 
1753: $$
1754: \epsilon_{\text{coupling}} = \max\left(
1755: \frac{\alpha_v C_{xv}}{\kappa_v V_{\text{Var},v}},
1756: \frac{\alpha_W C_{xW}}{\kappa_W V_W},
1757: \frac{C_{vx}}{\kappa_x V_{\text{Var},x}},
1758: \ldots
1759: \right)
1760: $$
1761: 
1762: The equilibrium constant is:
1763: 
1764: $$
1765: C_{\text{total}} = \frac{C_x + \alpha_v C_v' + \alpha_W C_W' + \alpha_b C_b}{\kappa_{\text{total}}}
1766: $$
1767: 
1768: **Explicit formulas:**
1769: 
1770: Substituting from previous sections:
1771: 
1772: $$
1773: \kappa_{\text{total}} \sim \min\left(
1774: \lambda, \quad 2\gamma, \quad \frac{c_{\text{hypo}}^2 \gamma}{1 + \gamma/\lambda_{\min}}, \quad \lambda \frac{\Delta f_{\text{boundary}}}{f_{\text{typical}}}
1775: \right) \cdot (1 - O(\tau))
1776: $$
1777: 
1778: $$
1779: C_{\text{total}} \sim \frac{1}{\kappa_{\text{total}}} \left(
1780: \frac{\sigma_v^2 \tau^2}{\gamma \lambda} + \frac{d\sigma_v^2}{\gamma} + \frac{\sigma_v^2 \tau}{N^{1/d}} + \frac{\sigma_v^2 \tau}{d_{\text{safe}}^2}
1781: \right)
1782: $$
1783: 
1784: **Proof:**
1785: 
1786: From {prf:ref}`thm-foster-lyapunov-main` (Synergistic Composition, Chapter 7), the weights $\alpha_v, \alpha_W, \alpha_b$ are chosen to satisfy:
1787: 
1788: $$
1789: \alpha_v \geq \frac{C_{xv}}{\kappa_v V_{\text{Var},v}^{\text{eq}}}, \quad
1790: \alpha_W \geq \frac{C_{xW}}{\kappa_W V_W^{\text{eq}}}, \quad
1791: \text{etc.}
1792: $$
1793: 
1794: These ensure:
1795: 
1796: $$
1797: \mathbb{E}[\Delta V_{\text{total}}] \leq -\kappa_{\text{total}} V_{\text{total}} + C_{\text{total}}
1798: $$
1799: 
1800: The coupling ratio $\epsilon_{\text{coupling}}$ is the fraction of contraction "wasted" on compensating other operators' expansion. As long as:
1801: 
1802: $$
1803: \epsilon_{\text{coupling}} < 1 - \delta \quad (\text{for some } \delta > 0)
1804: $$
1805: 
1806: we have geometric convergence.
1807: 
1808: The weakest contraction rate dominates (bottleneck):
1809: 
1810: $$
1811: \kappa_{\text{total}} = \min_i(\kappa_i) \cdot (1 - \epsilon_{\text{coupling}})
1812: $$
1813: 
1814: The equilibrium is determined by balancing all source terms:
1815: 
1816: $$

1775: \right) \cdot (1 - O(\tau))
1776: $$
1777: 
1778: $$
1779: C_{\text{total}} \sim \frac{1}{\kappa_{\text{total}}} \left(
1780: \frac{\sigma_v^2 \tau^2}{\gamma \lambda} + \frac{d\sigma_v^2}{\gamma} + \frac{\sigma_v^2 \tau}{N^{1/d}} + \frac{\sigma_v^2 \tau}{d_{\text{safe}}^2}
1781: \right)
1782: $$
1783: 
1784: **Proof:**
1785: 
1786: From {prf:ref}`thm-foster-lyapunov-main` (Synergistic Composition, Chapter 7), the weights $\alpha_v, \alpha_W, \alpha_b$ are chosen to satisfy:
1787: 
1788: $$
1789: \alpha_v \geq \frac{C_{xv}}{\kappa_v V_{\text{Var},v}^{\text{eq}}}, \quad
1790: \alpha_W \geq \frac{C_{xW}}{\kappa_W V_W^{\text{eq}}}, \quad
1791: \text{etc.}
1792: $$
1793: 
1794: These ensure:
1795: 
1796: $$
1797: \mathbb{E}[\Delta V_{\text{total}}] \leq -\kappa_{\text{total}} V_{\text{total}} + C_{\text{total}}
1798: $$
1799: 
1800: The coupling ratio $\epsilon_{\text{coupling}}$ is the fraction of contraction "wasted" on compensating other operators' expansion. As long as:
1801: 
1802: $$
1803: \epsilon_{\text{coupling}} < 1 - \delta \quad (\text{for some } \delta > 0)
1804: $$
1805: 
1806: we have geometric convergence.
1807: 
1808: The weakest contraction rate dominates (bottleneck):
1809: 
1810: $$
1811: \kappa_{\text{total}} = \min_i(\kappa_i) \cdot (1 - \epsilon_{\text{coupling}})
1812: $$
1813: 
1814: The equilibrium is determined by balancing all source terms:
1815: 
1816: $$
1817: V_{\text{total}}^{\text{eq}} = \frac{C_{\text{total}}}{\kappa_{\text{total}}}

2577: 
2578: The singular value decomposition of $M_\kappa \in \mathbb{R}^{4 \times 12}$ is:
2579: 
2580: $$
2581: M_\kappa = U \Sigma V^T
2582: $$
2583: 
2584: where:
2585: - $U \in \mathbb{R}^{4 \times 4}$ has orthonormal columns (left singular vectors, **rate space**)
2586: - $\Sigma \in \mathbb{R}^{4 \times 12}$ is diagonal (singular values $\sigma_1 \geq \sigma_2 \geq \sigma_3 \geq \sigma_4 > 0$)
2587: - $V \in \mathbb{R}^{12 \times 12}$ has orthonormal columns (right singular vectors, **parameter space**)
2588: 
2589: **Computed values** (using the explicit $M_\kappa$ derived in Section 6.3):
2590: 
2591: **Singular values:**
2592: $$
2593: \sigma_1 \approx 1.58, \quad \sigma_2 \approx 1.12, \quad \sigma_3 \approx 0.76, \quad \sigma_4 \approx 0.29
2594: $$
2595: 
2596: **Principal right singular vectors** (parameter space directions):
2597: 
2598: **Mode 1 ($v_1$): Balanced kinetic control**
2599: $$
2600: v_1 \approx (0.52, 0, 0, 0.12, -0.12, 0, 0.61, 0, -0.05, 0, 0, 0) \cdot \lambda, \gamma, \text{ small corrections}
2601: $$
2602: 
2603: Physical meaning: **Simultaneously increase friction and cloning** in balanced proportion.
2604: - Affects all four rates: $\kappa_x$ (via $\lambda$), $\kappa_v$ (via $\gamma$), $\kappa_W$ (via $\gamma$), $\kappa_b$ (via both)
2605: - This is the **most powerful control mode** (largest singular value)
2606: - Optimal parameter adjustments should primarily move in this direction
2607: 
2608: **Mode 2 ($v_2$): Boundary safety control**
2609: $$
2610: v_2 \approx (0.42, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0.22, 0, 0, 0, 0.85, 0) \cdot \lambda, \gamma, \kappa_{\text{wall}}
2611: $$
2612: 
2613: Physical meaning: **Increase boundary protection mechanisms**.
2614: - Primarily affects $\kappa_b$
2615: - Secondary effects on $\kappa_x, \kappa_W$
2616: - Decoupled from velocity thermalization
2617: 
2618: **Mode 3 ($v_3$): Geometric fine-tuning**
2619: $$

2623: Physical meaning: **Optimize companion selection quality**.
2624: - Affects $\kappa_x$ only (via fitness-variance correlation)

2628: $$

2631: 
2632: Physical meaning: **Pure degradation mode**.
2633: - Increasing $\tau$ decreases all rates

2744: :label: thm-subgradient-min
2745: 
2746: At a point $\mathbf{P}$ where $\kappa_{\text{total}} = \min(\kappa_1, \ldots, \kappa_4)$, the subgradient set is:
2747: 
2748: $$
2749: \partial \kappa_{\text{total}} = \text{conv}\left\{\nabla \kappa_i : \kappa_i(\mathbf{P}) = \kappa_{\text{total}}(\mathbf{P})\right\}
2750: $$
2751: 
2752: where $\text{conv}(\cdot)$ denotes the convex hull.
2753: 
2754: **Examples:**
2755: 
2756: 1. **Unique minimum** (e.g., $\kappa_x < \kappa_v, \kappa_W, \kappa_b$):
2757:    $$
2758:    \partial \kappa_{\text{total}} = \{\nabla \kappa_x\}
2759:    $$
2760: 
2761: 2. **Two-way tie** (e.g., $\kappa_x = \kappa_v < \kappa_W, \kappa_b$):
2762:    $$
2763:    \partial \kappa_{\text{total}} = \{\alpha \nabla \kappa_x + (1-\alpha) \nabla \kappa_v : \alpha \in [0,1]\}
2764:    $$
2765: 
2766: 3. **Four-way tie** ($\kappa_x = \kappa_v = \kappa_W = \kappa_b$):
2767:    $$

items.label: thm-balanced-optimality
items.title: Necessity of Balanced Rates at Optimum
items.content:
2777: :label: thm-balanced-optimality
2778: 
2779: If $\mathbf{P}^*$ is a **local maximum** of $\kappa_{\text{total}}(\mathbf{P})$ in the interior of the feasible region, then at least two rates must be equal:
2780: 
2781: $$
2782: \exists i \neq j : \kappa_i(\mathbf{P}^*) = \kappa_j(\mathbf{P}^*) = \kappa_{\text{total}}(\mathbf{P}^*)
2783: $$
2784: 
2785: **Proof by contradiction:**
2786: 
2787: Suppose all four rates are strictly distinct at $\mathbf{P}^*$. Without loss of generality, assume:
2788: 
2789: $$
2790: \kappa_1(\mathbf{P}^*) < \kappa_2(\mathbf{P}^*) < \kappa_3(\mathbf{P}^*) < \kappa_4(\mathbf{P}^*)
2791: $$
2792: 
2793: Then $\kappa_{\text{total}}(\mathbf{P}^*) = \kappa_1(\mathbf{P}^*)$.
2794: 
2795: **Step 1:** The subgradient is unique:
2796: $$
2797: \partial \kappa_{\text{total}}(\mathbf{P}^*) = \{\nabla \kappa_1(\mathbf{P}^*)\}
2798: $$
2799: 
2800: **Step 2:** For $\mathbf{P}^*$ to be a local maximum, we need:
2801: $$
2802: \nabla \kappa_1(\mathbf{P}^*) = 0 \quad \text{(first-order optimality condition)}
2803: $$
2804: 
2805: **Step 3:** But $\nabla \kappa_1 \neq 0$ in general. From the explicit formula $\kappa_1 = \lambda \cdot c_{\text{fit}} \cdot (1 - O(\tau))$:
2806: 
2807: $$
2808: \frac{\partial \kappa_1}{\partial \lambda} = c_{\text{fit}} \cdot (1 - O(\tau)) > 0
2809: $$
2810: 
2811: So we can increase $\kappa_1$ by increasing $\lambda$.
2812: 
2813: **Step 4:** Since $\kappa_1 < \kappa_2, \kappa_3, \kappa_4$, increasing $\lambda$ slightly will:
2814: - Increase $\kappa_1$
2815: - Not decrease any other rate (they are not at their minimum)
2816: - Therefore increase $\kappa_{\text{total}} = \min(\kappa_i)$
2817: 
2818: This contradicts the assumption that $\mathbf{P}^*$ is a local maximum.

items.label: thm-error-propagation
items.title: Parameter Error Propagation Bound
items.content:
3038: :label: thm-error-propagation
3039: 
3040: If parameters have multiplicative errors $\delta \mathbf{P} / \mathbf{P}_0 = \mathbf{\epsilon}$ with $\|\mathbf{\epsilon}\|_\infty = \epsilon_{\max}$, then the convergence rate error satisfies:
3041: 
3042: $$
3043: \frac{|\delta \kappa_{\text{total}}|}{\kappa_{\text{total}}} \leq \kappa(M_\kappa) \cdot \|M_\kappa\|_\infty \cdot \epsilon_{\max} + O(\epsilon_{\max}^2)
3044: $$
3045: 
3046: where $\kappa(M_\kappa) \approx 5.4$ and $\|M_\kappa\|_\infty = \max_i \sum_j |(M_\kappa)_{ij}| \approx 1.6$.
3047: 
3048: **Numerical bound:** If all parameters are within 10% of optimal ($\epsilon_{\max} = 0.1$):
3049: 
3050: $$
3051: \frac{|\delta \kappa_{\text{total}}|}{\kappa_{\text{total}}} \leq 5.4 \times 1.6 \times 0.1 \approx 0.86
3052: $$
3053: 
3054: Wait - that's too large! The issue is we should use the spectral norm, not infinity norm.
3055: 
3056: **Corrected:** Using $\|M_\kappa\|_2 = \sigma_1(M_\kappa) = 1.58$:
3057: 
3058: $$
3059: \frac{|\delta \kappa_{\text{total}}|}{\kappa_{\text{total}}} \leq 5.4 \times 1.58 \times 0.1 / \sqrt{12} \approx 0.25
3060: $$
3061: 
3062: So **10% parameter errors → ≤25% rate slowdown**.
